subject: Critical Thinking
title: Ibn al-Haytham: The First True Scientist
description: A quick, practical guide to Ibn al-Haytham: The First True Scientist.

hook.text: Before Galileo, before Bacon, an 11th-century Arab polymath invented the scientific method. His name: Ibn al-Haytham.

buildup.text: Working in Cairo, he wrote 'Kitab al-Manazir': the first work to insist that scientific claims must be verified by.

discovery.text: His method: question assumptions, design controlled experiments, measure results, & trust evidence over authority.

twist.text: He openly challenged ancient authorities, insisting that truth comes from reason and experimentation, not old texts.

climax.text: Ibn al-Haytham's experimental method predated European science by centuries.

punchline.text: Trust evidence, not authority. He said it a thousand years ago.

quiz.question: What was Ibn al-Haytham's revolutionary contribution to thinking?
options: Insisting that scientific claims must be verified by controlled experiments, not authority
